title_en: Archimedes and the Law of Buoyancy

summary.text_en: Archimedes discovered the law of buoyancy! The buoyant force on an object equals the weight of water it displaces. He also invented lever principle and Archimedes screw, greatest scientist of antiquity.
key_points_en: Buoyancy equals weight of displaced fluid
Lever principle: Give me a place to stand and I will move the Earth
Invented Archimedes screw and mechanical devices

story.text_en: Around 250 BC, the king asked Archimedes to verify if crown was pure gold. Archimedes pondered without solution. One day bathing, seeing water overflow, he had epiphany! He ran naked through streets shouting: 'Eureka! Eureka!' (I found it!) He realized he could measure crown volume by water displacement, thus calculating density.

fun_facts.text_en: 'Eureka' now means major discovery exclamation, originating from Archimedes' bathtub story.
Legend says he used giant mirrors to focus sunlight, setting Roman warships ablaze!
When Roman soldier invaded, he was drawing geometry, saying: 'Don't disturb my circles!' Then was killed.

experiment.description_en: Archimedes placed crown and equal-weight pure gold separately in water, measuring displaced water volume. If crown mixed with silver, volume larger, displacing more water. By comparing water displacement, could determine if crown pure gold. First time in human history using scientific method to test material purity!
experiment.why_en: Same mass of different substances, different densities, different volumes, different water displacement.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine sitting in bathtub, water overflows right? Your body pushes water away, water pushes you up - that's buoyancy! Water's push force exactly equals weight of water you displaced. That's why you feel lighter in water!

impact.text_en: Archimedes hailed as 'greatest mathematician and scientist of antiquity'. His buoyancy law and lever principle laid foundation for fluid mechanics and mechanics. His thinking influenced later scientists like Galileo and Newton, pioneering tradition of studying physics with mathematics.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Geometry foundation and rigorous proof methods
Connection between mathematics and natural laws

influenced.contribution_en: Inherited method of studying physics with mathematics

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Archimedes inherited Euclid's geometry tradition, applying mathematics to physical problems. His buoyancy law and lever principle became classical mechanics cornerstones. 2000 years later, Galileo rediscovered his works, Newton built complete mechanics system on this foundation. Pascal further developed hydrostatics.

quiz.question_en: According to Archimedes' principle, buoyant force on object in water equals what?
quiz.explanation_en: Archimedes' principle states: object immersed in fluid experiences upward buoyant force equal to weight of fluid displaced by object. This is the famous 'Eureka' moment discovery.
